verses.text: When David's time to die approached, he gave instructions to Solomon his son,
verses.comment: Opening of David's farewell address to Solomon.

verses.text: "I am about to go the way of all the earth. Be strong and show yourself a man,
verses.comment: David urges Solomon to be courageous as he prepares to die.

verses.text: and keep the charge of the LORD your God, to walk in his ways and to keep his statutes, his commandments, his rules, and his testimonies, as it is written in the Law of Moses, so that you may succeed in all that you do and wherever you turn,
verses.comment: Emphasizes obedience to God's law for success.

verses.text: that the LORD may keep his promise that he made regarding me, saying, 'If your sons are careful in their way, to walk before me in faithfulness with all their heart and with all their soul, you shall not lack a man on the throne of Israel.'
verses.comment: References the Davidic covenant.

verses.text: "Moreover, you know what Joab the son of Zeruiah did to me, how he dealt with the two commanders of the armies of Israel, Abner the son of Ner, and Amasa the son of Jether, whom he killed, shedding the blood of war in peace, and putting the blood of war on the belt around his waist and on the sandals on his feet.
verses.comment: Discusses Joab's killings—Abner and Amasa.

verses.text: Act according to your wisdom, but do not let his gray head go down to Sheol in peace.
verses.comment: "In peace" here means without punishment—David asks Solomon to act justly regarding Joab.

verses.text: But deal loyally with the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them be among those who eat at your table, for with such loyalty they came to me when I fled from Absalom your brother.
verses.comment: David rewards loyalty shown during Absalom's rebellion.

verses.text: There is also with you Shimei the son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, who cursed me with a grievous curse on the day I went to Mahanaim. But when he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the LORD, saying, 'I will not put you to death with the sword.'
verses.comment: Refers to David’s earlier oath to Shimei.

verses.text: Now therefore, do not hold him guiltless, for you are a wise man. You will know what you ought to do to him, and you shall bring his gray head down with blood to Sheol.
verses.comment: David tasks Solomon with holding Shimei accountable.

verses.text: Then David slept with his fathers and was buried in the city of David.
verses.comment: "Slept with his fathers" means "died and joined his ancestors."

verses.text: David ruled over Israel for forty years. He ruled seven years in Hebron, and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Summary of David's reign.

verses.text: Then Solomon sat on the throne of David his father, and his kingdom was firmly established.
verses.comment: Transition to Solomon's reign.

verses.text: Then Adonijah the son of Haggith came to Bathsheba the mother of Solomon. She said, "Do you come in peace?" He said, "In peace."
verses.comment: Adonijah seeks Bathsheba; greeting recalls earlier conflict.

verses.text: Then he said, "I have something to say to you." She said, "Speak."
verses.comment: No significant difference from standard text.

verses.text: He said, "You know that the kingdom was mine, and that all Israel looked to me to be king. But the kingdom has passed and become my brother's, for it was from the LORD.
verses.comment: Adonijah acknowledges God’s will in Solomon’s reign.

verses.text: Now I have one request to ask of you; do not refuse me." She said to him, "Speak."
He said, "Please ask King Solomon—he will not refuse you—to give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife."
verses.comment: Culturally, marrying a former royal consort would imply a claim to the throne.

verses.text: Bathsheba said, "Very well; I will speak for you to the king."

So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to talk to him about Adonijah. The king stood up to meet her, bowed to her, and sat down on his throne. Then he had a seat brought for the king’s mother, and she sat at his right hand.
verses.comment: Right hand is a place of honor.

verses.text: Then she said, "I have one small request to make of you; do not refuse me." The king said to her, "Ask, my mother, for I will not refuse you."
She said, "Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to your brother Adonijah as his wife."

King Solomon answered his mother, "Why do you ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask for him the kingdom as well—for he is my older brother—and ask for him, for Abiathar the priest and for Joab the son of Zeruiah too!"
verses.comment: Solomon understands the political implication.

verses.text: Then King Solomon swore by the LORD, saying, "God do so to me and more also if this word does not cost Adonijah his life!"
verses.comment: A typical oath formula.

verses.text: "Now as the LORD lives, who has established me and set me on the throne of David my father, and who has made me a house as he promised, surely Adonijah shall be put to death today."
So King Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and he struck him down, and he died.
verses.comment: Benaiah acts as royal executioner.

verses.text: And to Abiathar the priest the king said, "Go to Anathoth, to your fields, for you deserve death, but I will not put you to death at this time, because you carried the ark of the Lord GOD before David my father, and because you shared in all my father’s hardships."
verses.comment: Abiathar is spared due to past service.

verses.text: So Solomon expelled Abiathar from being priest to the LORD, fulfilling the word that the LORD had spoken concerning the house of Eli at Shiloh.
verses.comment: Abiathar’s removal fulfills prophecy concerning Eli’s house.

verses.text: When the news came to Joab (for Joab had followed Adonijah, although he had not followed Absalom), Joab fled to the tent of the LORD and took hold of the horns of the altar.
verses.comment: Horns of altar were a place of asylum, except for murderers.

verses.text: King Solomon was told, "Joab has fled to the tent of the LORD, and is beside the altar." Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying, "Go, strike him down."

So Benaiah came to the tent of the LORD and said to him, "The king commands, 'Come out.'" But he said, "No, I will die here." So Benaiah brought word back to the king, saying, "This is what Joab said, and this is how he answered me."
The king said to him, "Do as he has said. Strike him down and bury him, and so remove from me and from my father's house the guilt for the blood that Joab shed without cause.

The LORD will return his blood on his own head, because he struck down two men more righteous and better than himself, and killed them with the sword, but my father David did not know about it—Abner the son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah.
So their blood shall return on the head of Joab and on the head of his descendants forever; but for David and his descendants, his house and throne, there shall be peace from the LORD forever."
Then Benaiah the son of Jehoiada went up and struck him down and killed him. He was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
The king put Benaiah the son of Jehoiada over the army in place of Joab, and the king put Zadok the priest in the place of Abiathar.
verses.comment: Fulfills previous prophetic word regarding replacement of priest.

verses.text: Then the king sent for Shimei and said to him, "Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and stay there, and do not go out from there to any place whatever.
For on the day you go out and cross the brook Kidron, know for certain that you shall surely die; your blood shall be on your own head."
verses.comment: Solomon sets a clear, conditional warning.

verses.text: Shimei said to the king, "What you say is good; as my lord the king has said, so your servant will do." So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for many days.
But after three years, two of Shimei's slaves ran away to Achish, son of Maacah, king of Gath. When it was told to Shimei, "Look, your slaves are in Gath,"
Shimei arose and saddled his donkey and went to Gath to Achish to seek his slaves. Shimei went and brought his slaves from Gath.
When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had returned,

the king sent and summoned Shimei and said to him, "Did I not make you swear by the LORD and solemnly warn you, saying, 'On the day you leave and go to any place, know for certain that you shall die'? And you said to me, 'What you say is good; I will obey.'
Why then have you not kept the oath of the LORD and the commandment I gave you?"
The king also said to Shimei, "You know in your heart all the evil you did to David my father. So the LORD will return your evil on your own head.
But King Solomon shall be blessed, and the throne of David will be established before the LORD forever."
So the king gave the command to Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he went out and struck down Shimei, and he died. So the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.
verses.comment: Summary conclusion of Solomon's consolidation of the kingdom.
